Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a high performance matrix-assisted laser ionization dual time-of-flight (MALDI/TOF-TOF) mass spectrometer (MS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Programs. Professor Carolyn Cassady from University of Alabama Tuscaloosa and colleagues Yuping Bao, Jason Bara, Marco Bonizzoni and Paul Rupar are acquiring a matrix assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometer with collision induced dissociation (CID) capabilities (MALDI/TOF-TOF MS.) In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex samples. MALDI TOF combines gentle ionization (ideal for producing intact ions of peptides, proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, synthetic polymers, and other similarly sized species) with a detection mode that offers an excellent balance between sensitivity and accuracy across a wide mass range. This highly sensitive technique allows identification and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the university and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse students with this modern analytical technique. It is also used in outreach activities, such as the annual Alabama Advanced Instrumental Techniques Colloquium (AITC), which exposes undergraduate students from throughout the region to state-of-the-art instrumentation. Students in an NSF Research experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program in chemistry and materials science also use the MALDI/TOF-TOF MS.

This mass spectrometer enhances research and education at all levels. It aids researchers in developing techniques for the analysis and sequencing of acidic peptides using deprotonated ions and for characterizing structures, molecular weights and other properties of polymer-ionene hybrids. The MALDI/TOF-TOF MS is used to examine iron oxide nanoparticle platforms for a variety of biomolecules and polymers. The instrumentation is also used for characterizing host-guest complexes of hyperbranched polyelectrolytes and analyzing polyimines produced by anionic ring opening polymerizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF MRI grant was for the purchase of a matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization tandem time-of-flight mass spectrometer (MALDI/TOF-TOF MS) to be used for research and teaching at The University of Alabama (UA) in Tuscaloosa.  The instrument, a Bruker rapifleX, was installed in June 2018.  To date, it has been employed to further the activities of 19 research groups at UA, including students and faculty from the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry (13 groups), the UA Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering (4 groups), and the Department of Biological Sciences (2 groups).  MALDI/TOF-TOF MS has broad applications in characterizing low volatility samples by providing molecular mass and structural information.  This research at UA, which has included the training of about 25 graduate students on use of the MALDI/TOF-TOF MS, has made extensive use of the depth and versatility of the technique. The three graduate students who have most extensively used this instrument have recently obtained their PhDs in Chemistry and are now pursuing careers in industry and academics that employ the skills that they learned using the MALDI/TOF-TOF.  Projects employing the rapifleX in UA research have included sequencing peptides using collision-induced dissociation (Cassady), characterization of organic polymers and their synthesis routes (Rupar and Bara), elucidation of the presence of oligonucleotides in biological samples (Dunkle), identification the compounds found on electrode and quantum dot materials by MALDI imaging (Pan), development of MALDI matrices using iron oxide nanoparticles (Bao) and chromium complexes (Cassady), determination of the structures of synthesized porphyrins (Bonizzoni) and organometallic complexes (Papish), identification of peptides and other biomolecules in biological samples (Frantom, Woski, Kim), and characterization of plant materials by both single stage MALDI/TOF and location of the physical sites of these compounds by MALDI imaging (Ciesla and Kersch-Becker).  Six additional research groups have employed the MALDI/TOF-TOF in more routine, but still important, analysis of polymer, material, and biological samples.  To date, this work has resulted 15 peer-reviewed publications and 18 presentations by at scientific conferences or universities.  In addition, the MALDI/TOF-TOF has been used in undergraduate research projects by two regional undergraduate institutions:  the University of Montevallo employed it to analysis porphyrin samples, while the work of Stillman College (an HBCU) involved DNA analysis.  The rapifleX has also been employed in two UA undergraduate teaching laboratories at UA, biochemistry lab (CH 463) and instrumental analysis (CH 424).  Both experiments were developed at UA specifically for the MALDI/TOF-TOF MS and involved the characterization of biomolecules.  To date, they have exposed about 42 undergraduate science majors to the technique. (Unfortunately, plans to have a near equal number of undergraduates use the MALDI/TOF-TOF in spring 2020 were cancelled due to Covid-19).  The instrument has also been employed to analyze about 45 samples over the past two years from three small biotechnology companies (Hinge Bio, TACS Labs, and Thrupore Technologies).  Outreach activities to expose researchers and the general public to the capabilities of this instrument have included a workshop on the use of mass spectrometry (January 2019, ~80 attendees, students and faculty from UA and neighboring undergraduate institutions), an open house with demonstrations to the College Leadership Board (September 2019, >50 attendees from the general public), a lab tour with demonstrations to the Southeast Undergraduate Research Conference in Chemistry and Biochemistry (January 2020, ~100 attendees, undergraduate students and faculty from the region), and lab tours with instrument demonstrations to potential graduate students in chemistry and biochemistry (March 2019 and March 2020, ~26 attendees).
